questions.question: The alternative minimum tax (AMT) applies when:

options.B: Tentative minimum tax exceeds regular tax liability
options.C: The taxpayer claims more than three exemptions
options.D: Adjusted gross income exceeds $500,000

questions.explanation: AMT is the excess of tentative minimum tax over regular tax liability. If regular tax equals or exceeds tentative minimum tax, no AMT is owed. The calculation compares two tax systems and requires payment of the higher amount.
questions.tip: AMT = Tentative minimum tax - Regular tax (if positive). No AMT if regular tax ≥ TMT.

questions.question: Which of the following is an AMT preference item that is added back to taxable income when computing alternative minimum taxable income (AMTI)?

options.D: Personal exemptions

questions.explanation: Interest on private activity bonds (other than for exempt facilities) is tax-exempt for regular tax but is an AMT preference item. It must be added back when computing AMTI.
questions.tip: Private activity bond interest is a key AMT preference—tax-exempt for regular tax, taxable for AMT.

questions.question: For 2024, the AMT exemption amount for a married couple filing jointly is approximately:
questions.explanation: For 2024, the AMT exemption is approximately $133,300 for married filing jointly ($85,700 for single filers). The exemption phases out at higher income levels—beginning at $1,218,700 for MFJ.
questions.tip: 2024 AMT exemption: ~$133K MFJ, ~$86K single. Phases out at higher AMTI.

questions.question: What are the AMT tax rates for individuals?

options.D: 28% flat rate

questions.explanation: Individual AMT is computed at 26% on the first $220,700 of AMTI over the exemption (2024, MFJ), and 28% on AMTI exceeding that amount. Capital gains retain their preferential rates.
questions.tip: Individual AMT rates: 26% then 28%. Capital gains keep preferential rates.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, state and local taxes (SALT) deducted for regular tax purposes:

options.D: Are partially deductible based on income

questions.explanation: SALT deductions (income, property, sales taxes) are not allowed for AMT purposes. This is one of the largest AMT adjustments for individuals in high-tax states.
questions.tip: SALT: $10K cap for regular tax, completely disallowed for AMT.

questions.question: A taxpayer paid $15,000 in AMT due to timing differences (such as ISO exercise). In a future year when regular tax exceeds tentative minimum tax, what relief is available?

options.B: The AMT credit can offset regular tax
options.D: The AMT is deductible on Schedule A

questions.explanation: AMT paid on timing (deferral) items creates an AMT credit that can be used in future years when regular tax exceeds tentative minimum tax. This prevents permanent double taxation on timing items.
questions.tip: AMT credit: Relief for timing-related AMT. Usable when regular tax > TMT in future years.

questions.question: An employee exercises incentive stock options (ISOs), paying $10 per share when the FMV is $50 per share, for 1,000 shares. What is the AMT adjustment?

options.D: $50,000 positive adjustment

questions.explanation: ISO exercise creates an AMT adjustment equal to the bargain element (FMV minus exercise price). Here: ($50 - $10) × 1,000 = $40,000 positive adjustment to AMTI. This is the most common cause of AMT for tech employees.
questions.tip: ISO AMT adjustment = (FMV - exercise price) × shares. Major AMT trigger.

questions.question: For real property placed in service after 1998, what is the AMT depreciation adjustment?

options.A: Use 150% declining balance instead of MACRS
options.C: No adjustment—same depreciation for regular and AMT
options.D: Use ADS recovery period

questions.explanation: For real property placed in service after 1998, there is no AMT depreciation adjustment—the same straight-line method applies for both regular tax and AMT. Prior rules required longer recovery periods for AMT.
questions.tip: Post-1998 real property: No AMT depreciation adjustment. Same for regular and AMT.

questions.question: A taxpayer deducts interest on a home equity loan used to pay off credit card debt. For AMT purposes, this interest is:

options.D: Deductible only if itemized for regular tax

questions.explanation: Home equity interest is only deductible if used to buy, build, or substantially improve the home (acquisition debt). Interest on home equity debt used for other purposes (like paying credit cards) is not deductible for either regular tax or AMT under current law.
questions.tip: Home interest deduction requires acquisition debt use—not just home equity debt.

questions.question: A married couple filing jointly has AMTI of $1,318,700 in 2024. The exemption begins phasing out at $1,218,700. How much of the $133,300 exemption remains?
questions.explanation: The exemption phases out at 25% of AMTI over the threshold. Excess = $1,318,700 - $1,218,700 = $100,000. Phase-out = $100,000 × 25% = $25,000. Remaining exemption = $133,300 - $25,000 = $108,300.
questions.tip: AMT exemption phase-out: Reduce exemption by 25% of AMTI over threshold.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $50,000 AGI and $6,000 in medical expenses. What is the medical expense deduction for AMT purposes?
questions.explanation: For AMT, the medical expense floor is 7.5% of AGI (same as regular tax after TCJA). Deduction = $6,000 - (7.5% × $50,000) = $6,000 - $3,750 = $2,250. Wait, that's the regular tax amount. For AMT, the floor was historically 10% but is now 7.5%. So: $6,000 - $3,750 = $2,250 for both.
questions.tip: Medical deduction floor: 7.5% of AGI for both regular tax and AMT (post-TCJA).

questions.question: Under TCJA (2018-2025), a taxpayer who claims the standard deduction for regular tax purposes has what AMT impact?

options.A: Must add back the standard deduction for AMT
options.C: Can claim the standard deduction or itemize for AMT
options.D: Must itemize for AMT regardless of regular tax choice

questions.explanation: Under TCJA, the AMT exemption was increased significantly and standard deduction filers are unlikely to owe AMT. The standard deduction is not an AMT preference item. The higher exemption and other changes largely eliminated AMT for standard deduction filers.
questions.tip: TCJA raised AMT exemption dramatically—standard deduction filers rarely owe AMT now.

questions.question: An investor in the 35% tax bracket considering private activity bonds should be aware that:

options.A: Interest is fully tax-exempt for all purposes
options.B: Interest may trigger AMT, reducing the effective yield
options.C: Bonds are not available to individual investors
options.D: Interest is taxable for both regular tax and AMT

questions.explanation: Private activity bond interest is generally exempt from regular tax but is an AMT preference. Investors subject to AMT may find the effective yield reduced because the interest creates AMT liability.
questions.tip: PABs: Tax-free for regular tax, but AMT preference. Check AMT status before investing.

questions.question: The corporate alternative minimum tax reinstated by the Inflation Reduction Act applies to corporations with average annual adjusted financial statement income exceeding:

options.D: $1 billion

questions.explanation: The 15% corporate AMT (CAMT) under the IRA applies to corporations with average annual adjusted financial statement income (AFSI) exceeding $1 billion over a 3-year period. It uses book income as the base.
questions.tip: Corporate AMT (2023+): 15% on book income for companies with >$1B average AFSI.

questions.question: Which item is classified as an AMT preference (always positive adjustment) rather than an AMT adjustment (positive or negative)?

options.C: Percentage depletion in excess of basis
options.D: ISO bargain element

questions.explanation: Percentage depletion in excess of basis is an AMT preference item—it's always added back. SALT disallowance, depreciation differences, and ISO bargain elements are adjustments that can be positive or negative depending on circumstances.
questions.tip: Preferences always increase AMTI; adjustments can increase or decrease AMTI.

questions.question: An employee holds ISOs with a $100,000 bargain element. To minimize AMT exposure, the employee should consider:

options.A: Exercising all options in a single year for efficiency
options.B: Spreading exercises across multiple years to stay below AMT threshold
options.C: Converting ISOs to NQSOs before exercise
options.D: Waiting until the stock price declines

questions.explanation: Spreading ISO exercises over multiple years can keep each year's AMT adjustment below the exemption amount, avoiding AMT entirely. This requires modeling each year's tax situation to optimize the exercise timing.
questions.tip: ISO AMT strategy: Calculate max bargain element per year to stay below AMT threshold.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $50,000 of AMT credit carryforward from prior years. In 2024, regular tax is $80,000 and tentative minimum tax is $60,000. How much AMT credit can be used?
questions.explanation: The AMT credit can reduce regular tax only to the level of tentative minimum tax. Here, regular tax ($80,000) minus TMT ($60,000) = $20,000 maximum credit usage. The remaining $30,000 credit carries forward.
questions.tip: AMT credit use = Regular tax - TMT. Cannot reduce tax below TMT.

questions.question: For an investor regularly subject to AMT, which type of municipal bond is most advantageous?

options.A: Private activity bonds with highest yield
options.B: General obligation bonds from any state
options.D: Any tax-exempt bond—all are equivalent for AMT

questions.explanation: Essential function (governmental purpose) municipal bonds are exempt from both regular tax and AMT. For AMT-sensitive investors, these provide true tax-free income. Private activity bonds create AMT exposure despite being regular tax-exempt.
questions.tip: AMT investors: Choose essential function/governmental munis, not private activity bonds.

questions.question: A taxpayer expects to be subject to AMT in 2024 but not in 2025. Which strategy is most beneficial?

options.D: Accelerate state tax payments and defer income

questions.explanation: Since SALT is not deductible for AMT, prepaying provides no benefit in an AMT year. Deferring property taxes to 2025 (a non-AMT year) allows deduction when it provides regular tax benefit. Consider accelerating income if AMT rates are lower than expected 2025 rates.
questions.tip: In AMT years, SALT deductions are worthless. Defer SALT to regular tax years.

questions.question: A taxpayer has suspended passive losses from a limited partnership investment. For AMT purposes, these losses:

options.B: Must be recomputed using AMT adjustments
options.D: Are deductible up to $25,000

questions.explanation: Passive losses must be separately computed for AMT using AMT income and expense amounts (including AMT depreciation). This creates a separate AMT passive loss carryforward that may differ from the regular tax carryforward.
questions.tip: Maintain separate passive loss calculations for regular tax and AMT.

questions.question: A construction company uses the completed contract method for regular tax. For AMT purposes, it must use:

options.D: Accrual method

questions.explanation: For AMT, long-term contracts must generally be accounted for using the percentage of completion method, even if completed contract is used for regular tax. This creates timing differences that result in AMT adjustments.
questions.tip: Long-term contracts: Percentage of completion for AMT, even if completed contract for regular tax.

questions.question: An AMT NOL can offset what percentage of AMTI (before the NOL deduction)?

options.D: 80% for post-2017 losses, 100% for pre-2018 losses

questions.explanation: Post-2017 NOLs can offset only 80% of taxable income (and AMTI) due to TCJA limitations. Pre-2018 NOLs could offset 90% of AMTI. The 80% limit applies to both regular tax and AMT for current losses.
questions.tip: AMT NOL limit: 80% of AMTI for post-2017 losses (same as regular tax limit).

questions.question: An employee exercises ISOs and sells the stock on the same day (disqualifying disposition). What is the AMT consequence?

options.B: No AMT adjustment—disqualifying disposition eliminates it
options.D: AMT adjustment equals capital gain

questions.explanation: A same-day sale (disqualifying disposition) converts the ISO to ordinary income treatment. Since there's no longer a timing difference between regular tax and AMT, no AMT adjustment is created.
questions.tip: ISO same-day sale = disqualifying disposition = no AMT adjustment (but ordinary income).

questions.question: How are charitable contributions treated for AMT purposes?

options.D: Deductible only for cash contributions

questions.explanation: Charitable contributions are allowed as a deduction for both regular tax and AMT. There is no AMT adjustment for charitable contributions—they're treated the same under both systems.
questions.tip: Charitable deductions: Same for regular tax and AMT. No adjustment needed.

questions.question: Interest on a mortgage used to acquire a primary residence is deductible for AMT purposes on debt up to:

options.D: No limit for AMT

questions.explanation: Under TCJA, acquisition debt interest is deductible on mortgages up to $750,000 (for loans after 12/15/2017) for both regular tax and AMT. Pre-TCJA loans up to $1,000,000 are grandfathered.
questions.tip: Acquisition debt interest: Same limits for regular tax and AMT ($750K post-TCJA).

questions.question: The foreign tax credit for AMT purposes is:

options.B: Limited to 90% of tentative minimum tax before FTC
options.D: Equal to the regular tax FTC

questions.explanation: The AMT foreign tax credit is computed separately and is limited to 90% of the tentative minimum tax (before the FTC). This prevents the FTC from fully eliminating AMT liability.
questions.tip: AMT FTC: Computed separately, limited to 90% of pre-FTC tentative minimum tax.

questions.question: An employee exercises ISOs in March when FMV is $100/share (exercise price $20). By December 31, the stock price drops to $30. The bargain element for AMT is based on:

options.D: The lower of exercise date or year-end FMV (Section 83(b) election)

questions.explanation: The AMT adjustment is based on FMV at exercise date ($100 - $20 = $80/share). The year-end decline doesn't reduce the AMT adjustment. This creates the painful 'AMT trap' where tax is owed on gains that evaporated.
questions.tip: ISO AMT trap: Adjustment based on exercise-date FMV. Stock decline doesn't help.

questions.question: Under the corporate alternative minimum tax (CAMT), which adjustment applies to book income to arrive at adjusted financial statement income (AFSI)?

options.A: Add back state and local taxes
options.C: Adjust for covered benefit plan contributions
options.D: Add back percentage depletion

questions.explanation: AFSI adjustments include items like pension contributions (difference between book expense and actual contributions), financial statement NOLs, and adjustments for certain tax credits. Depreciation is generally based on book amounts, not ADS.
questions.tip: CAMT: Starts with book income, with limited adjustments (pension, NOLs, certain credits).

questions.question: A taxpayer incurs $100,000 of intangible drilling costs and elects to expense them for regular tax. For AMT, the excess IDC preference is:

options.B: $100,000 minus what would have been allowed under 10-year amortization
options.D: Zero if net oil and gas income is positive

questions.explanation: The IDC preference is the excess of current-year expensed IDCs over the amount that would have been allowed if capitalized and amortized over 10 years. In year 1: $100,000 - $10,000 = $90,000 preference.
questions.tip: IDC preference = Expensed amount - 10-year straight-line amortization amount.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $100,000 AMT credit carryforward. To maximize credit usage, the taxpayer should:

options.A: Accelerate income to create regular tax liability
options.B: Defer deductions to increase regular tax relative to TMT
options.C: Make estimated payments equal to prior year AMT
options.D: Both A and B are valid strategies

questions.explanation: AMT credit is usable when regular tax exceeds TMT. Both accelerating income (increases regular tax) and deferring deductions (increases regular tax more than TMT) can increase the gap and allow more credit usage.
questions.tip: AMT credit strategy: Widen the gap between regular tax and TMT in credit years.

questions.question: Before 2018 (when corporate AMT was repealed) and after 2022 (new CAMT), what is the gross receipts test for the current corporate AMT?

options.C: $1 billion average adjusted financial statement income
options.D: No gross receipts test—applies to all C corporations

questions.explanation: The new CAMT (2023+) applies to corporations with average annual AFSI exceeding $1 billion over 3 years. This is much higher than the old corporate AMT exemption thresholds. Very few corporations are subject to CAMT.
questions.tip: New CAMT (2023+): Only applies to largest corporations ($1B+ average AFSI).

questions.question: A high-income taxpayer in a high-tax state wants to model AMT exposure. Which factor is LEAST likely to trigger AMT under current law (2018-2025)?

options.B: High state and local tax deductions
options.D: Multiple personal exemptions

questions.explanation: TCJA eliminated personal exemptions (2018-2025), so this is not an AMT factor during this period. SALT disallowance (B), ISO exercises (A), and private activity bond interest (C) remain significant AMT triggers.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA AMT triggers: ISOs, SALT (already limited), PAB interest. Not personal exemptions.

questions.question: An employee exercises ISOs and pays AMT on the bargain element. When the stock is eventually sold (qualifying disposition), the basis for AMT purposes is:

options.B: The exercise price plus the bargain element (FMV at exercise)
options.D: Original exercise price plus AMT paid

questions.explanation: For AMT, basis includes the bargain element since that amount was included in AMTI at exercise. This higher basis reduces the AMT gain on sale and helps recover the AMT previously paid through the AMT credit mechanism.
questions.tip: ISO AMT basis = Exercise price + bargain element. Creates AMT credit on sale.

questions.question: For AMT purposes, long-term capital gains are taxed at:

options.B: The same preferential rates as regular tax (0%/15%/20%)
options.D: 28% collectibles rate for all gains

questions.explanation: Capital gains retain their preferential rates (0%, 15%, 20%) for AMT purposes. They are not subject to the 26%/28% AMT rates. Net investment income tax (3.8%) may still apply based on modified AGI.
questions.tip: Capital gains: Same preferential rates for both regular tax and AMT.

questions.question: A tax advisor is calculating the 'crossover point' where a client shifts from regular tax to AMT. Which calculation determines this point?

options.B: Where regular tax equals tentative minimum tax
options.C: Where total deductions equal the AMT exemption
options.D: Where AGI exceeds the phase-out threshold

questions.explanation: The crossover point is where regular tax liability equals tentative minimum tax. Beyond this point, additional AMT adjustments create actual AMT liability. Below this point, AMT adjustments don't increase total tax.
questions.tip: AMT crossover: Regular tax = TMT. Beyond this, AMT adjustments matter.
